document.docAuthor: Scarbrough Table Of Contents, Aubrey G.
document.docTitle: Afroestricus Scarbrough Table Of Contents 2005, gen. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Afroestricus, a new Afrotropical Ommatine (Diptera: Asilidae) genus with twenty species and two species groups

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Afroestricus, a new Afrotropical Ommatine (Diptera: Asilidae) genus with twenty species and two species groups

mods:name.mods:namePart: Scarbrough Table Of Contents, Aubrey G.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species:
Ommatius macroscelis Bezzi 1906: 294
, by present designation.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2. Character states of
Afroestricus
Scarbrough. 1. Head of
Afroestricus chiastonureus (Speiser)
in lateral view. 2. Apex of fore femur of
Afroestricus chiastonureus (Speiser)
showing a preapical anteroventral bristle. Abbreviations: Ocellar seta=Oc; Preapical anteroventral bristle= Pab.

FIGURES 3–4. Character states of the wing and postocular bristles of the subgenus
Afroestricus
Scarbrough. 3a–b. Wing venation of the
macroscelis
and the
minutus
species groups. 4a–b. Short, erect and long, thin, postocular bristles bristles. Abbrevations: First radial cell=r 1 ; fourth radial cell=r 4 ; discal cell=d; radial­medial crossvein=r­m; first medial cell=m 1 ; third medial cell=m 3 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Thorax: Scutellum usually with two black marginal bristles and prominent preapical marginal groove. Stout anepimeral bristle present. Wing ( Figs. 3a–3b ): Entirely microtrichose, usually brownish­yellow, sometimes brown or yellow. Legs: Fore femur ( Fig. 2 ) with preapical, anteroventral bristle. Hind femur with two ventral rows of bristles, each extending from base to apex; posteroventral row of bristles usually arched medially onto posterior surface. Tarsi partially yellow, at least a few yellow bristles present. Apical segments of abdomen of females usually with sparse, unusually stout, bristles. Terminalia (5–192). Male: Cerci unusually long and narrow, three or more times as long as wide. Epandrium notched dorsally or apically, with a short flat flange along internal surface apically. Aedeagal sheath strongly produced [=epiphallus] anteriorly, concealing tubular distiphallus dorsally and usually apex laterally; distiphallus usually horizontal, apex somewhat flattened laterally, often pointed and recurved; base of aedeagus produced anteriorly, projecting between gonocoxites and beyond hypandrium, usually wide and rounded. Female: Spermatheca tubular, recurved except in
A. minutus
, usually slightly flattened and wider apically, sides gradually wider apically; spermathecal duct unusually narrow, including valves, each connected to large bulbus bursa basally ( Fig. 24 ) and spermatheca preapically. Sternum 8 with minute spurlike ridge apically. Genital fork mostly membranous, arms sclerotized dorsally.

Etymology.
Afroestricus
is a combination of the prefix Afro for the Afrotropical region where the species occurs and the Latin estricis for eating in excess, referring to the voracious feeding habits of asilids. The gender is feminine.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Distribution of
Afroestricus species
by country.

tr.td: Kenya Tanzania Rwanda Burundi Congo Malawi Zambia Angola Namibia Mozambique Botswana Zimbabwe
Mali Senegal Ghana Nigeria Cameroon Chad Yemen Eriticea Ethiopia Uganda

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Afroestricus
is distinguished from
Ommatius
by the moderately gibbose face; frons with wide stripe of long setae, not arranged in single file; ocellar setae subequal to or as long as three antennal segments combined ( Fig. 1 ); fore femur with anterior, preapical bristle ( Fig. 2 ); the flat, rooflike epiphallus which conceals the tubular distiphallus dorsally; the notched epandrium and the tubular, recurved, slightly flattened spermatheca.
